linear_equations.name: Linear Equations
linear_equations.content:
Linear Equations

An equation that makes a straight line when graphed. It has the form: ax + b = 0 where a ≠ 0.

Key Points:
  • Standard form: ax + b = 0
  • Solution: x = -b/a
  • Can have one solution, no solution, or infinite solutions
  • Graph is always a straight line
Example:

Solve 2x + 4 = 0
2x = -4
x = -2

Practice Problems:
  1. 3x + 9 = 0
  2. 5x - 15 = 0
  3. 2x + 7 = 3x - 2

quadratic_equations.name: Quadratic Equations
quadratic_equations.content:
Quadratic Equations

An equation of the form ax² + bx + c = 0 where a ≠ 0.

Key Points:
  • Standard form: ax² + bx + c = 0
  • Solutions found using quadratic formula: x = [-b ± √(b² - 4ac)]/2a
  • Discriminant (b² - 4ac) determines nature of roots
  • Graph is a parabola
Example:

Solve x² - 5x + 6 = 0
(x - 2)(x - 3) = 0
x = 2 or x = 3

Discriminant Rules:
  • If b² - 4ac > 0: Two real roots
  • If b² - 4ac = 0: One real root (repeated)
  • If b² - 4ac < 0: No real roots (complex)

inequalities.name: Inequalities
inequalities.content:
Inequalities

Mathematical expressions involving <, >, ≤, or ≥.

Key Rules:
  • Adding/subtracting same number preserves inequality
  • Multiplying/dividing by negative number FLIPS the inequality
Examples:

Solve 2x + 3 > 7
2x > 4
x > 2

Solve -3x < 12
x > -4 (flipped when dividing by -3)

polynomials.name: Polynomials
polynomials.content:
Polynomials

Expressions with variables and coefficients using operations +, -, ×.

Key Terms:
  • Degree: Highest power of variable
  • Coefficient: Number multiplied by variable
  • Constant term: Term with no variable
Operations:

Addition: (2x² + 3x) + (4x² - 2x) = 6x² + x

Multiplication: (x + 2)(x + 3) = x² + 5x + 6

limits.name: Limits
limits.content:
Limits

The value that a function approaches as the input approaches some value.

Key Points:
  • Notation: lim(x→a) f(x) = L
  • Left-hand limit and right-hand limit must be equal
  • Used to define continuity and derivatives
Common Limits:
  • lim(x→0) sin x / x = 1
  • lim(x→∞) 1/x = 0

derivatives.name: Derivatives
derivatives.content:
Derivatives

Measures the rate of change of a function.

Key Rules:
  • Power Rule: d/dx(xⁿ) = nxⁿ⁻¹
  • Constant Rule: d/dx(c) = 0
  • Sum Rule: d/dx(f + g) = f' + g'
Examples:

d/dx(x³) = 3x²

d/dx(5x²) = 10x

integration.name: Integration
integration.content:
Integration

The reverse process of differentiation.

Key Rules:
  • Power Rule: ∫xⁿ dx = xⁿ⁺¹/(n+1) + C, n ≠ -1
  • ∫1/x dx = ln|x| + C
  • ∫eˣ dx = eˣ + C
Definite Integrals:

∫ₐᵇ f(x) dx = F(b) - F(a), where F is antiderivative

basic_ratios.name: Basic Trigonometric Ratios
basic_ratios.content:
Trigonometric Ratios

Relations between angles and sides of right triangles.

Definitions:
  • sin θ = opposite/hypotenuse
  • cos θ = adjacent/hypotenuse
  • tan θ = opposite/adjacent
Reciprocal Ratios:
  • csc θ = 1/sin θ
  • sec θ = 1/cos θ
  • cot θ = 1/tan θ

identities.name: Trigonometric Identities
identities.content:
Important Identities

Pythagorean Identities:
  • sin²θ + cos²θ = 1
  • 1 + tan²θ = sec²θ
  • 1 + cot²θ = csc²θ
Double Angle:
  • sin 2θ = 2 sin θ cos θ
  • cos 2θ = cos²θ - sin²θ

newtons_laws.name: Newton's Laws of Motion
newtons_laws.content:
Newton's Laws of Motion

First Law (Law of Inertia):

An object at rest stays at rest, and an object in motion stays in motion with the same speed and direction unless acted upon by an unbalanced force.

Second Law (F = ma):

Force equals mass times acceleration (F = ma)

Third Law (Action-Reaction):

For every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction.

Applications:
  • Car safety features (seatbelts, airbags)
  • Rocket propulsion
  • Walking (push backward, ground pushes forward)

kinematics.name: Kinematics
kinematics.content:
Kinematics Equations

Motion without considering forces.

Key Equations:
  • v = u + at
  • s = ut + ½at²
  • v² = u² + 2as

Where: u = initial velocity, v = final velocity, a = acceleration, t = time, s = displacement

work_energy.name: Work and Energy
work_energy.content:
Work-Energy Theorem

Work:

W = F × d × cos θ (Force × displacement × angle between them)

Kinetic Energy:

KE = ½mv²

Potential Energy:

PE = mgh (gravitational)

Conservation of Energy:

Total energy remains constant: KE₁ + PE₁ = KE₂ + PE₂

wave_properties.name: Wave Properties
wave_properties.content:
Wave Characteristics

Key Terms:
  • Wavelength (λ): Distance between crests
  • Frequency (f): Number of waves per second
  • Amplitude: Height of wave
  • Velocity: v = fλ
Types:
  • Transverse: Particles move perpendicular (light waves)
  • Longitudinal: Particles move parallel (sound waves)

sound.name: Sound Waves
sound.content:
Sound Physics

Properties:
  • Speed in air: ~343 m/s at 20°C
  • Loudness: Related to amplitude
  • Pitch: Related to frequency
Doppler Effect:

Change in frequency due to relative motion between source and observer.

reflection.name: Reflection
reflection.content:
Laws of Reflection

Angle of incidence = Angle of reflection

Types:
  • Specular: Smooth surfaces (mirrors)
  • Diffuse: Rough surfaces (paper)
Mirror Equation:

1/f = 1/u + 1/v where f = focal length, u = object distance, v = image distance

refraction.name: Refraction
refraction.content:
Snell's Law

n₁sin θ₁ = n₂sin θ₂

Key Concepts:
  • Refractive index: n = c/v (speed in vacuum/speed in medium)
  • Total internal reflection occurs when angle > critical angle
  • Applications: Lenses, prisms, fiber optics

mean.name: Mean (Average)
mean.content:
Mean (Arithmetic Mean)

The sum of all values divided by the number of values.

Formula:

μ = (Σx)/n for population
x̄ = (Σx)/n for sample

Key Points:
  • Affected by outliers
  • Most common measure of central tendency
  • Used for interval and ratio data
Example:

Data: 4, 8, 6, 5, 3
Mean = (4+8+6+5+3)/5 = 26/5 = 5.2

median.name: Median
median.content:
Median

The middle value when data is arranged in order.

Key Points:
  • Not affected by outliers
  • For odd n: middle value
  • For even n: average of two middle values
  • Used for ordinal, interval, ratio data
Example (odd):

Data: 3, 5, 7, 9, 11
Median = 7

Example (even):

Data: 2, 4, 6, 8
Median = (4+6)/2 = 5

mode.name: Mode
mode.content:
Mode

The most frequently occurring value.

Key Points:
  • Can have multiple modes (bimodal, multimodal)
  • Only measure for nominal data
  • May not exist if all values unique
Example:

Data: 2, 3, 3, 3, 5, 7, 7, 9
Mode = 3 (appears 3 times)

range.name: Range
range.content:
Range

The difference between maximum and minimum values.

Formula:

Range = Maximum - Minimum

Key Points:
  • Simple to calculate
  • Affected by outliers
  • Only uses two values

variance.name: Variance
variance.content:
Variance

Average of squared deviations from the mean.

Formulas:

σ² = Σ(x - μ)²/N (population)

s² = Σ(x - x̄)²/(n-1) (sample)

Key Points:
  • Measures spread of data
  • Square of standard deviation
  • Always non-negative

standard_deviation.name: Standard Deviation
standard_deviation.content:
Standard Deviation

Square root of variance.

Formulas:

σ = √[Σ(x - μ)²/N] (population)

s = √[Σ(x - x̄)²/(n-1)] (sample)

Key Points:
  • Most common measure of spread
  • Same units as original data
  • 68-95-99.7 rule for normal distributions

basic_concepts.name: Probability Fundamentals
basic_concepts.content:
Basic Probability

Definition:

P(Event) = (Favorable outcomes)/(Total possible outcomes)

Rules:
  • 0 ≤ P(E) ≤ 1
  • P(not E) = 1 - P(E)
  • Sum of all probabilities = 1

addition_rule.name: Addition Rule
addition_rule.content:
Addition Rule of Probability

For Mutually Exclusive Events:

P(A or B) = P(A) + P(B)

For Non-Mutually Exclusive Events:

P(A or B) = P(A) + P(B) - P(A and B)

multiplication_rule.name: Multiplication Rule
multiplication_rule.content:
Multiplication Rule of Probability

For Independent Events:

P(A and B) = P(A) × P(B)

For Dependent Events:

P(A and B) = P(A) × P(B|A)

variables.name: Variables and Data Types
variables.content:
Variables and Data Types

Common Data Types:
  • Integer: Whole numbers (int)
  • Float: Decimal numbers
  • String: Text (str)
  • Boolean: True/False (bool)
Variable Rules:
  • Must start with letter or underscore
  • Case-sensitive
  • Cannot use reserved keywords

control_structures.name: Control Structures
control_structures.content:
Control Flow

Conditional Statements:
if condition:    # If statement
    # code here
elif condition:  # Else if
    # code here
else:            # Else
    # code here
Loops:
# For loop
for i in range(5):
    print(i)

# While loop
while condition:
    # code here

functions.name: Functions
functions.content:
Functions

Reusable blocks of code.

Syntax:
def function_name(parameters):
    # code here
    return value
Example:
def add(a, b):
    return a + b

result = add(5, 3)  # result = 8

arrays.name: Arrays/Lists
arrays.content:
Arrays and Lists

Ordered collections of elements.

Operations:
  • Access: list[index]
  • Add: list.append(item)
  • Remove: list.remove(item)
  • Length: len(list)

stacks_queues.name: Stacks and Queues
stacks_queues.content:
Stacks (LIFO)

Last In, First Out. Like a stack of plates.

  • push: Add to top
  • pop: Remove from top

Queues (FIFO)

First In, First Out. Like a line of people.

  • enqueue: Add to back
  • dequeue: Remove from front

parts_of_speech.name: Parts of Speech
parts_of_speech.content:
Parts of Speech

Eight Main Parts:
  • Noun: Person, place, thing (cat, city)
  • Pronoun: Replaces noun (he, she, it)
  • Verb: Action or state (run, is)
  • Adjective: Describes noun (beautiful, tall)
  • Adverb: Describes verb (quickly, very)
  • Preposition: Shows relationship (in, on, at)
  • Conjunction: Connects words (and, but)
  • Interjection: Exclamation (wow, ouch)

tenses.name: Verb Tenses
tenses.content:
English Verb Tenses

Simple Tenses:
  • Present: I walk
  • Past: I walked
  • Future: I will walk
Continuous Tenses:
  • Present: I am walking
  • Past: I was walking
  • Future: I will be walking

main_idea.name: Finding Main Idea
main_idea.content:
Identifying Main Ideas

Tips:
  • Read the first and last sentences of paragraphs
  • Look for repeated words/phrases
  • Ask: 'What is this mostly about?'
  • Supporting details give examples or evidence

inference.name: Making Inferences
inference.content:
Drawing Conclusions

Reading between the lines - understanding what's implied but not directly stated.

Tips:
  • Use context clues
  • Connect to prior knowledge
  • Consider character actions and dialogue
  • Look for cause and effect
